Award.AwardTitle: Theta Functions for Polarized Calabi-Yau Varieties
Award.AbstractNarration:
The main objective of the proposed research is to generalize the classical theory of theta functions for Abelian varieties to polarized Calabi-Yau varieties, both open (i.e. log) and compact, more precisely: to give a canonical basis for the vector space of global sections, and a formula for the structure constants for the multiplication rule in the coordinate ring, expressed in the canonical basis, determined by counts of rational curves on the mirror. The existence of such generalized theta functions points to the existence of geometrically meaningful compactification of the moduli space, vastly generalizing the Mumford-Namikawa-Alexeev-Olsson compactificaton of A_{g,d}, and the Gelfand-Kapranov-Zelevinski-Alexeev-Olsson theory of the secondary polytope, and at the same time suggests a synthetic construction of the mirror as Proj of the canonically described ring. The proposal includes a detailed scheme for carrying this out in dimension two, and for cluster varieties of all dimensions.

The main proposal is that a broad class of geometric objects, so called Calabi-Yau varieties, come with a natural system of coordinates. Informally: If you live on a Calabi-Yau variety, there should be natural, intrinsic quantities in your world, whose values determine your precise position. As these geometric objects play a fundamental role in diverse areas of mathematics, these intrinsic quantities should play a similar fundamental role. More broadly, string theory models suggest that WE live on a Calabi-Yau, and thus the proposal suggests there are such fundamental quantities, not yet understood, in our world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mathematicians and scientists use coordiante systems all the 

time --- a system of addresses for specifying a point in space.  The

same object will usually admit infinitely many different coordinate

systems: Consider the surface of a flat table that extends

infinitely in all directions. To give a coordinate system

we draw a grid on the table. There are infinitely many different grid

systems we could draw . E.g.  take one system, and now rotate it

a bit, you get an entirely different one, there is no apparant 

advantage of one over the other. What this means is that there

is no such thing as the "absolute address" of a point on the object,

E.g. there is so intrinsic  origin, or (0,0) point on our infinite table. You

can make any point (0,0) by adjusting the coordinate system.  The reason

is that the table top is completely symmetric. No one point can be

intrinsically distinguished from any other point; all the points 

look the same.

 

The surprising

idea behind the proposal is that for a very important class of geometric

objects, so called Calabi-Yau manifolds,  the situation is exactly

the opposite of this infinite table: These objects actually come with

an intrinsic coordinate system, what the researchers call Theta Functions.

These objects are thus completely asymmetric, any two points can be

intrinsically distinguished, any two points "look different".

The idea is important because Calabi-Yaus,

and thus these intrinsic Theta functions, come up in diverse areas of

mathematics. They are potentially even interesting to physicists, because

in the string theory model, our universe itself is one of these Calabi-Yaus,

and so our world may have these as yet undiscovered and exploited

intrinsic coordinates.
